headline: PRESIDENT GREETS COMBAT MARINES
lead_paragraph: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., April 30—President Nixon wel comed home from Vietnam to clay the vanguard of the First Marine Division with a pledge to end the war “in a way worthy of your service.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Medal of Honor Winner Killed in Detroit Store Holdup
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, April 30 (AP) — A Michigan man who won the Medal of Honor for bravery in Vietnam was shot and killed today by a store owner who said the soldier had tried to rob him.

headline: G.I. Patrol Attacked In the Ashau V alley; 5 Killed and 10 Hurt
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 1 (AP)—North Viet namese troops ambushed reconnaissance patrol of Amer ican paratroopers in Ashau Valley, killing five and wound ing 10, the United States com mand reported today.

headline: Bunkers Seized Near Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 (Reuters)—American troops uncovered a strongly fortified bunker complex yes terday less than half a mile from a heavily traveled road northwest of here and fought an eight‐hour battle to cap ture it, the United States com mand reported today.

headline: Two Teachers Start Class to Help Veterans Find Jobs
lead_paragraph: In the dusty room over looking Rivington Street, the class of Vietnam veterans bent over their work. “You wouldn't believe the bitter ness that comes out here,” the teacher said. “It's as if they suddenly realized they left one war and now they're in the middle of another one.”
author: By Paul L. Montgomery

headline: Saigon Evicts a Critic
lead_paragraph: Saigon's eviction order to Don Luce, 36‐year‐old Amer ican social worker turned correspondent, is a blow at the right of the American people to know the truth about a conflict in which their Government is still expending lives and resources at a prodigious rate.

headline: U.S. Command in Vietnam Bars ‘Battle Hymn of Calley’ From Radio Network, Citing Pending Appeal
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 — The American Armed Forces Radio Network in Vietnam, “where the hits just keep on coming,” has been told to stop playing “The Bat tle Hymn of Lieutenant Calley.”
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘What Good Came of It at Last?’
lead_paragraph: AHMADABAD, India — The English poet Robert Southey (1774–1843) wrote an admirable poem, “After Blenheim.” It could have been written about Indo china. The battle of Blenheim was fought in Bavaria in August, 1713, when the English and their allies, under the Duke of Marlborough and Prince Eugene of Savoy, gave a crushing de feat to the French and their allies.
author: By Homi K. Dastur

headline: 330 PROTESTERS HELD IN CAPITAL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 30— The police arrested today 330 members of a civil rights and antiwar group conducting a week‐long “peoples' lobby” in the capital.

headline: Lawyers Stage Rally to Protest War
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of lawyers took to the streets here yesterday in an uncharacteristic protest against the war in Vietnam.
author: By Lesley Oelsner

headline: Threat to Peace Coalition
lead_paragraph: A small group of disrupters, putting their revolu tionary fantasies above the cause of peace, are nibbling away the effectiveness of last week's impressive mass appeals to end the war in Vietnam. The thrill‐seeking chaos of the fringe groups' Washington encampment and the escalation of their upheavals, including plans to paralyze Washington traffic next Monday, appear de signed to attract those domestic guerrillas whose primary interest Is in political warfare.

headline: Times Sq. Table Tennis Accents P.O.W. Plight
lead_paragraph: A 24‐hour table tennis match is being played on a traffic island in Times Square by wives, mothers and chil dren of men who are prison ers of war or missing in action in Southeast Asia.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON— The antiwar pro tests in the capital are based on the notion that if you keep people from going to their offices in Washington you interfere with the efficiency and policies of the Government, but this is obviously ridiculous.
author: By James Reston

headline: Headliners
lead_paragraph: ‘Miracle’

headline: Hospital Ship Leaves Danang
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 1 (AP)—The United States hospital ship Sanctuary sailed from Danang harbor today, clos ing out four years of duty in the Vietnam war zone. Officials said the 27‐year‐old ship would be retired upon her return to the United States.

headline: PRESIDENT VOWS ACTIONS TO SPUR ECONOMIC UPTURN
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 1—President Nixon said today that he would do everything in his power, even seek a tax cut if necessary, to keep the econ omy on an upward curve.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The decision of the Department of Justice to ask for the dismissal of an injunction against veterans demon strating against the war—an injunc tion which the Government had pressed as an emergency In the United States District Court for the District of Columbia through a three‐judge panel of the Court of Appeals to the Supreme Court —bespeaks contempt for the judicial processes which were invoked. [Editorial April 24.]
author: David R. Hood

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—“This is going to be our last big fight,” an American officer said before the allied op eration in the Ashau Valley be gan. But subsequent events have not borne out his prediction.
author: —Wer Peterson

headline: Mr. Nixon's Nyet
lead_paragraph: There is much to be said for President Nixon's argu ment, repeated at his latest news conference, that setting a date for American withdrawal from Vietnam would “destroy any incentive the enemy might have to nego tiate.” But that argument loses much of its force when the Administration rejects out of hand two new Commu nist peace proposals in Paris, as it did that very day. Limited and ambiguous as those proposals are, they deserve exploration, if only because they include an overture for secret talks.

headline: Account of Writers' Ouster Disputed by South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: A spokesman here for the South Vietnamese Government said yesterday that a dispatch in The New York Times on Wednesday contained an error in its account of how Don Luce, an American writer, was ordered to leave South Viet nam.

headline: President's War Powers Face State and Federal Legal Tests
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, May 1—In at least 10 state capitals as well as in Washington, lawmakers have begun to question the ex tent of the President's author ity in undeclared wars such as Vietnam.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52's Attack Ambush Area in Ashaul
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May I (AP) — United States R.52 bombers staged new raids in the Ashau Valley sector in the north Saturday in an at tempt to strike at North Viet namese troops who ambushed an American patrol.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—“A promise to dis cuss means nothing from the North Vietnamese,” President Nixon said at his news conference. Maybe not, but would be hard to prove it the way the President tried to do.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Vietnam Veteran Seeks Discharge as Objector
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 1 (UPI)—An Army major, a vet eran of Vietnam, filed suit in Federal District Court this week asking his discharge on the ground that he is a con scientious objector.

headline: Fears and Resentments of Vietnamese Living Near American Bases Are Reflected in Agency Surveys
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1—American officials in Saigon are now learning of the distrust and anger felt by many Vietnamese who live near American military bases, and how much they resent the be havior of American soldiers toward them.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: MAYDAY MARCHES ENLIST FEW HERE
lead_paragraph: Rallies and marches blos somed left, right and center for May Day in the city yesterday, but crowds at the scattered demonstrations were generally sparse and the impact minimal.
author: By Paul L. Montgomery

headline: Troops Mass Near Capital as Protesters Assemble
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON May 1— Several thousand armed Federal troops from nearby states rolled into the capital's suburbs tonight to support policemen and National Guardsmen in dealing with threatened civil disobedience on Monday.

headline: Better Jobless Pay Urged For Veterans of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) —A bipartisan group of 45 Congressmen has introduced legislation to guarantee a mini mum unemployment benefit for Vietnam veterans of $75 week for up to 52 weeks.

headline: Transcript of President's San Clemente News Conference on Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference in San Clemente, Calif., yesterday, as re corded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

headline: 30,000 Protesters Routed in Capital
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2—The metropolitan police ordered 30, 000 antiwar protesters from their encampment on the banks of the Potomac in a sudden strike that began just after dawn today.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: A.D.A. ADVOCATES NIXON IMPEACHMENT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) —Americans for Democratic Action urged Congress today to impeach President Nixon for “high crimes” in Indochina and to create a commission to in vestigate the conduct of the war.

headline: Fulbright and Percy Worried by Protests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) —Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that he was wor ried that the actions of the antiwar protesters in Washington might jeopardize chances for Senate passage of a bill setting a date for withdrawal of United States forces from Vietnam.

headline: Muskie Expects Country To ‘Recapture Excitement’
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May 2 (UPD— Senator Edmund S. Muskie said today that the war in Indochina had caused Americans to lose confidence in their country but that it would “recapture thit sense of excitement about both our past and our future.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If only the people of this country would unite behind our President to day, then Hanoi would get the mes sage tomorrow and the war would be over before the dawn of another day.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 2—There was a rally in London recently in behalf of George Jackson, the black prisoner who wrote “Soledad Brother,” and Angela Davis, who is charged with complicity in the kidnap and murder of a California judge by Jackson's brother Jonathan and others. It was in many ways an extraordinary public meeting for Lon don.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:No wonder there is a credibility gap. May I quote from the April 26 issue of The Times:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Burke Marshall can, of course, speak for himself as to the meaning of his comments (Op‐Ed April 10), but Maj. Gen. John H. Cushman's letter (April 26) misses the point of the question of war waged against civilians in Viet nam. Since missing the point has be come an endemic intellectual failure in modern America, the difference here worth pointing out.

headline: The Mayday Tribe: ‘Creativeness, Joy and Life Against Bureaucracy and Grim Death’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2—The Mayday Tribe says that “May day is an action, a time period, a state of mind and a bunch of people.”
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: KILLING OF CIVILIANS LAID TO A GENERAL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) —An Army brigadier general is under investigation by mili tary officials for allegedly shooting to death six Vietna mese civilians as he flew over them in 1968, Pentagon sources said today

headline: Foe Remains Elusive in Ashau Valley
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2—The South Vietnamese Army has reported no new con tact with the enemy in its 18‐ day‐old operation in the moun tains around the Ashau Valley.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Jet Attacks in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Monday, May 3 (Reuters)—A United States Air Force Phantom fighter‐bomber attacked an antiaircraft posi tion in North Vietnam late yes terday, the United States mili tary command announced to day.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: South Vietnam Rail Strike
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 3 (Reuters)—South Viet nam's coastal railroad system virtually came to a halt today when almost 4,000 rail workers conducted their first strike, 24‐hour action to underline requests for wage increases.

headline: Humphrey Assails A.D.A. On Impeachment of Nixon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) —Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey, Democrat of Minnesota, today described as irresponsible and unwarranted the resolution adopted by Americans for Democratc Action calling for the impeachment of President Nixon.

headline: Resor, in Vietnam, Expects Difficulties As Troops Pull Out
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 4—Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor, ending a 10‐day review of the Vietnamization program today, said that “while progress to date is encouraging, a difficult period lies ahead” because of the continuing pullout of United States troops.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Washington Does Most of Its Business as Usual
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 3— Rush hour came two hours early, around 5:30 this morn ing.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: Weary Protesters Say They Were Not Prepared For Police Action
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 4—“I don't feel we have ac complished our objectives—we weren't prepared for the police and their tactics.”

headline: Nixon Is Kept Informed On Actions by Police
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE. Calif., May 3 (UPI)—President Nix on kept in close touch today with the developments in the antiwar demonstrations in Washington, the Western White House said.

headline: 7,000 Arrested in Capital War Protest; 150 Are Hurt as Clashes Disrupt Traffic
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 4—About 7,000 antiwar protest ers were arrested yesterday morning after fighting running skirmishes with metropolitan police and Federal troops throughout large areas of the nation's capital.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Empty Victory
lead_paragraph: Aimed at shutting down the Federal Government, the “Mayday” demonstrations in Washington from the outset had much more potential for suffering and tragedy than for practical effect on Vietnam war policy. Because of skillful work by the Washington police backed by Fed eral troops, this tragic potential did not materialize.

headline: Nixon Bids Hanoi Back a Swedish P.O.W. Plan
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 3—President Nixon called on North Vietnam today to take advantage of an offer by Swe den to intern prisoners of war for the duration of the Vietnam ese conflict.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: When prize‐winning pic ture was made last May 4, Mr. Filo was 21‐year‐old photography student at Kent State University . . . Was also a summer intern news photographer for two small Pennsylvania newspapers, the Valley Daily News of Taren tum and The Daily Dispatch of New Kensington ... Says he closed photo lab on troubled campus “to get some lunch” and took his camera with him as usual. . . “I was curious about the situ ation . . . I went with my camera to get some pictures just for myself...” First be lieved National Guard was firing blanks . . . Stunned when he realized live ammu nition was being used. . . Prize‐winning photo appeared in thousands of newspapers here and abroad and became a symbol of protest against Vietnam war . . . Mr. Filo, a native of Natrona Heights, Pa., will be graduated this summer from Kent State. . . Was married last December to Marge Emerson of Natrona Heights.

headline: Thousands of Washington Demonstrators Held Outdoors Before Releases Start
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 4—The 7,000 arrests here yesterday filled the courtyard of the District of Columbia Jail for several hours and clogged the city's courts.
author: By Ben A. Franklin Special to The New York Times

headline: FORGE IN VIETNAM CUT 8,000 IN WEEK
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 4 (AP)—The yesterday that American mili tary strength in Vietnam drop ped by 8,000 troops last week, the second largest weekly reduction this year.

headline: U.S. Concedes It Hit Enemy Hospitals
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 3—The Defense Department acknowl edged today that allied forces in South Vietnam had destroyed enemy hospitals, but it contend ed that such actions had oc curred because these installa tions were not marked.

headline: Saigon Plans Holiday Truce
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 4 (Reuters) — Vietnam will observe a cease fire Sunday to observe the anni versary of Buddha's birth, presidential spokeman an nounced here today.

headline: Antiwar Editorialist Retires
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, May 3 (UPI)— Robert Lasch, who won the 1065 Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing, has retired as editorial page editor of The St. Louis Post‐Dispatch. Mr, Lasch, 64 years old, won the Pulitzer Prize for his editorials denounc ing the Vietnam war.

headline: Senators Lining Up for Visas to China
lead_paragraph: Washington Notes
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: THRONG FORECAST BY ‘VICTORY NOW’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4 — The Rev. Carl McIntire, the right‐wing, fundamentalist preacher, declared today that his Victory Now in Vietnam March here this Saturday would attract more participants than did the peace march of April 24.
author: By Philip Shabecoff Special to The New York Times

headline: 2,680 More Demonstrators Arrested in Washington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 5—The District of Colum bia police arrested 2,680 more antiwar demonstrators yester day in minor confrontations and at the end of a two‐hour dem onstration at the Justice De partment.
author: By Ben A. Franklin Special to The New York Times

headline: Mayday Tribe Introduces New Element to Protests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4— They came into the dawn like a ragamuffin army, handker chiefs around their necks for the gas, uniformed in a motley of dungarees, field jackets and hiking boots, most of them with long hair.
author: By John Kifner Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Praises Workers Who Stayed on the Job
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) —President Nixon repeated today his commendations of the police authorities for their handling of the antiwar pro testers and praised Govern ment workers who stayed on the job.

headline: ROCKETS AGAIN HIT U.S. BASE AT DANANG
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 5 (AP) — Enemy gunners launched their third rocket attack in 12 days on the sprawling United States air base at Danang before dawn today and shelled several other United States and allied instal lations in South Vietnam.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4—What the latest spring madness in Washington proves, if anything, is that the people are sick of violence—the violence of the war and the mob action of the antiwar demonstrators as well.
author: By James Reston

headline: U.S. War Dogs Begin Return From Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4 — The Air Force began bringing home its dogs from Vietnam today.

headline: Violence Brings a Change in Tactics of Capital Police
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4—To the heightened violence of the Mayday demonstrators, law en forcement here has responded with new tactics that modify— perhaps purposely—the picture of the District of Columbia police as unfailingly genteel hosts to the nation's dissenters.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: New Table for Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 4 (AP)—A table tennis set shipped here by Michigan couple in an effort to get the Vietnam peace talks rol ling has arrived and is expected to be delivered to the con ferencesite Thursday. Mr. and Mrs. John Reid of Whitehall, Mich., said they hoped that the gift would be a step toward peace, in line with the apparent thaw after a United States table tennis team visited China.

headline: Police Tear Gas Disperses War Foes at Wisconsin U.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis., May 4 (AP) —The police used tear gas to night to disperse an antiwar rally at the University of Wis consin after they said burning objects were hurled at a cam pus construction project.

headline: Strongly Anti‐Red South Vietnamese Faction Raising a Political Stir in Hue
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2—A resurgence of deep anti Communist feeling in Central Vietnam and impatience with what is considered to be lenien cy in rounding up Communist sympathizers are causing politi cal repercussions in the old imperial city of Hue.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Guards Aid Protester
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4 (Reu ters)—A teen‐age antiwar dem onstrator arrested by the Wash ington police found help today in raising his bail money from an unexpected source — his guards. The youth had only $4 instead of the $10 needed for bail when he was arrested yes terday. But members of the Na tional Guard contributed the rest of the money.

headline: The F.B.I. Homes In and Gets Its Man
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4 — There was a note of surprise in an F.B.I. agent's voice as he reported on a Justice De partment radio frequency this afternoon that John Froines was speaking to thousands of antiwar demonstrators — right under Attorney General John N. Mitchell's office window.

headline: HANOI COOL TO PLAN OF U.S. ON PRISONERS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 4 (AP)—North Vietnam today in effect reject ed a United States proposal that prisoners of war from both sides be held in a neutral coun try.

headline: Antiwar Move Defeated in Assembly
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, May 4—The As sembly took up the issue of the war in Vietnam today, and few members walked out In disgust, some fidgeted rest lessly and most sat mute.
author: By Francis X. Clines Special to The New York Times

headline: Dow Chemical Announces A 3‐for‐2 Split of Its Stock
lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Mich., May 5— The Dow Chemical Company declared a three‐for‐two stock split today and increased its cash dividend at an annual rate of 10 cents a share.
author: By Gerd Wilcke Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52 Raids Increased
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 5 (AP) — An increase in B‐52 raids was reported today against targets in the north western corner of South Viet nam and the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

headline: Metcalf Hits Policeman Barring Entry to Capitol
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) —Senator Lee Metcalf, Dem ocrat of Montana, punched a policeman in the chest today when he stopped him from crossing a police line during antiwar demonstrations at the Capitol.

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 5—Early in the first act of “The Peace Freak Follies of 1971,” a piece of street thea ter which mercifully self‐destructed here this week before the second act could begin, that familiar old bore, Irate Motorist, jumped from his stalled car on Pennsylvania Avenue and, waving a long club, began chasing a batch of Youthful Demonstrators. One of them fell and Irate Motorist closed upon him for mayhem, or so we thought.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: Most Rallies in U.S. Peaceful; Sporadic Violence Mars Three
lead_paragraph: Most antiwar demonstrations held across the nation yester day were peaceful, but sporadic violence marked those in San Francisco and at the University of Wisconsin and the Univer sity of Maryland.
author: By Grace Lichtenstein

headline: PROTESTERS FAIL TO SLOP CONGRESS; POLICE SEIZE 1,146
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 5 — Antiwar protesters massed on the marble steps outside the House of Representatives to day to demand that Congress ratify a “people's treaty” with North Vietnam to end the war in Southeast Asia.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: The Challenge of Confrontation
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Clashes Get Attention Abroad but Little Comment
lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 5 — This week's antiwar demonstrations in Washington have attracted wide but not overwhelming at tention in Europe. Press com ment has been relatively muted, though with some criticism of the Washington police for their mass arrest tactics.

headline: Foe Recaptures Town in Laos At Flank of Ho Chi Minh Trail
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, May (UPI)—A Laotian town, on the western flank of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network has fallen to North Vietnamese troops aft er two days of heavy fighting.

headline: WAR RALLY HERE ATTRACTS 10,000
lead_paragraph: More than 10,000 people gathered at Bryant Park yester day to commemorate the killing of students at Kent State Uni versity and Jackson State Col lege a year ago and to protest against the war in. Vietnam.
author: By James F. Clarity

headline: 3 Representatives Decry Arrests on Capitol Steps
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 5 — “Don't you guys believe in the Constitution?” Representative Bella S. Abzug, her gaucho hat askew on her head, shouted Representative Roman C. Pu cinski, Democrat of Illinois, the foot of the House steps.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: INSTANT RESPONSES TO NIXON TV URGED
lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union has called on the heads of the three broadcast net works to provide time for “im mediate response” to televised Presidential speeches by per sons holding opposing views.

headline: Enemy Shells Danang
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, May 6 (Reuters) — Vietcong gunners shelled the northern base city of Danang last night, killing six civilians and destroying three houses, a military spokes man announced here today. The spokesman said three soldiers and four civilians were wounded in the shelling attack just before midnight.

headline: A Deaf Boy at Protest Is Helped by Policeman
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 5— A teen‐age boy, wandering aimlessly on the Mall today near the Capitol, got instruc tions on how to take part in an antiwar demonstration from an unlikely source—a District of Columbia police man.

headline: Hoffman Arrested By F.B.I. for Role In Capital Protest
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) —Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader at his Manhattan apartment late tonight on charges of interstate travel to incite a riot and as saulting a police officer during antiwar demonstration here.

headline: Saigon Reports New Clash in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6 (AP) — South Vietnamese troops, led by tanks and under cover of air and artillery strikes, reported fighting about 400 North Vietnamese today near the town of Snuol, a few miles inside Cambodia.

headline: 2 WAR FOES FACE U.S. JURY INQUIRY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 6—As 18 days of antiwar protest wound down here today, the Justice Department was seeking a grand jury investigation of at least two participants who were arrested on conspiracy charges.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: What Went Wrong?
lead_paragraph: “A new Republican Administra tion will arm the American people with the truth.”—Richard Nixon, 1968.
author: By Emmet John Hughes

headline: Westchester Revisited: Recent Issues a Dim Memory
lead_paragraph: Three years after leaving Westchester County for as signments in Germany and Vietnam, a correspondent who lived and worked in the county from 1966 to 1968 returned to see what had happened on a range of is sues that have troubled this and other suburban areas.WHITE PLAINS—For those who watched or joined the civil rights demonstrations at the construction site in New Rochelle that bitter winter of 1966–67, the now‐completed glittering shopping mall and Macy's store will always evoke memories of protesters blocking the snowy excava tion.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: BILL WOULD HELP ADDICT VETERANS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 6—Rep resentative Paul G. Rogers, Democrat of Florida, announced today that he was introducing legislation to add $10‐million immediately to Veterans Ad ministration programs for treat ment of narcotics addicts and to require the armed forces to treat addicts before returning them to civilian life.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Tines

headline: Kent State Sit‐in Ends
lead_paragraph: KENT, Ohio, May 6 (UPI)— About 50 antiwar students to day abandoned their two‐day sit‐in at entrances to a Kent State University building that houses the R.O.T.C. head quarters.

headline: Ohio State Demonstration
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6 (AP) — About 100 demonstra tors shouted antiwar slogans and threw eggs, mud and marshmallows at R.O.T.C. (cadets during a military review at Ohio State University today.

headline: U.S. Bids Hanoi Discuss Own Pullout
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 6—The United States said at the Vietnam peace talks today that there could be no negotiations on total withdrawal of American troops unless the withdrawal of North Vietnamese troops was also included.

headline: Giant U.S. ‘Plows’ Clear Scrub Along Foe's Route
lead_paragraph: DUCHUE, South Vietnam, May 6—The flat, fertile land scape of this former rice paddy district is undergoing one final disfigurement of war. After having been dug up by the enemy for bunkers and tunnels, and, after the bomb ing, defoliation and napalm, the Rome Plows—giant United States Army buildozers—are now cutting through the re maining scrub and abandoned farms to leave the soil bare, gray and lifeless.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 130 Arrested in Antiwar Protest at Federal Building in Boston
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, May 6—A crowd of demonstrators estimated at between 2,000 and 4,000 per sons laid siege to the John F. Kennedy Federal Building today in a protest against the Indo china war.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Protest In Buffalo
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, May 6 (AP)— Antiwar protesters, clapping hands and chanting “We Want Peace Now,” paraded in a cir cle at the entrance to the Fed eral Building in downtown Buf falo today.

headline: Cambodia Shelves Plan for Closer Taiwan Relations
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6 —Cambodia has quietly shelved consideration of a proposal by Nationalist China that the two countries exchange embassies and has delayed sending a per manent diplomatic mission to Taipei.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Says Planes Destroy Antiaircraft Guns in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 8 (AP) — Two American fighter‐bombers de stroyed three antiaircraft guns in North Vietnam yesterday, the United States command re ported.

headline: Repression on Capitol Hill
lead_paragraph: The arrest of more than a thousand persons on the steps of the Capitol on Wednesday brought the week's antiwar protests to an ominous climax. In a crass display of arbitrary power, the constitutional rights of these citizens were ignored as they were hauled off to a makeshift detention center. It was a spectacle of lawless ness and repression hardly to be expected in a republic of free men.

headline: INQUIRY IS THWARTED BY EX‐G.I.'S SILENCE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 7—The Army and a former sergeant have reached an impasse over whether he will divulge more information about an alleged killing of about 30 Vietnamese civilians by American soldiers in April, 1969.

headline: 2,000 AT MARYLAND U. DISPERSED BY GUARD
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 7 (UPI) — Acting under orders from Gov. Marvin Mandel, Na tional Guard troops using tear gas swept the University of Maryland campus today to rout 2,000 antiwar demonstrators who attempted to disrupt classes and tossed a tear gas canister into a cyclotron. A 9 P.M. curfew was imposed.

headline: For Mother's Day
lead_paragraph: BRONXVILLE, N. Y.—Mother's Day, 1971, marks the third anniversary of our son's death in Vietnam. It also marks the third anniversary of the Paris peace talks. Once again we moth ers cry “Peace,” but there is no peace.
author: By Louise Bristol Ransom

headline: 10 IN HOUSE OPEN AN ANTIWAR TOUR
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, May 7—Presi dent Nixon never had a plan to end the Vietnam war and still does not, Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Demo crat of the Bronx, said here today as he and nine other House members began a barn storming effore in behalf of peace efforts.

headline: Capital Jail Is Ruled ‘Cruel’ Punishment
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 7 — A judge ruled here today that 600 persons arrested during antiwar demonstrations were being held under conditions that inflicted “cruel and un usual punishment.”
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Peggy Duff

headline: SAIGON ASKING PARIS TO RENEW RELATIONS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, South Vietnam, May 7 — South Vietnam's Foreign Minister announced here today that his country was seeking to re‐establish diplomatic relations with France.

headline: Censure of Dellums Urged
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) — Clay Claiborne, national di rector of a group called the Black Silent Majority Commit tee, urged the House today to censure Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of Cali fornia, for his support of recent antiwar demonstrations. A spokesman for Mr. Dellums, who is black, dismissed the committee as a Republican front organization and asked, “Who is the black silent major itv?”

headline: Avedon Photographs a Harsh Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam —Richard Avedon, the American portrait photographer who came to Vietnam six weeks ago to take pictures for his new book, believes that all Americans who choose to come to Vietnam have one terrible thing in common.”
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: National Hypocrisy
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In intervening in the Calley case, President Nixon has unintentionally performed a valuable public service: He has illuminated the wide gulf which separates stated national goals from national actions. Such diverse elements as the outcry about prisoners of war in North Vietnam, our South American policy, the issue of law and order here at home all have this basic dichotomy in common.
author: Ben Hubby; M.D. Mound Bayou, Miss., April 23, 1971

headline: Day's Allied Ce se‐Fire Marks Buddha's Birthday
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8—United States and South Vietnamese armed forces began a 24‐hour truce in South Vietnam at noon today in honor of Buddha's birthday, but the fighting in Cambodia and the bombing of enemy supply routes in Laos are continuing.
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Unlikely Officer Fighting Ouster
lead_paragraph: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, May 6—Second Lieut. Rory J. Sutton of Algonac, Mich., does not look or act like an Army officer. His hair hangs too far over his eyes, he does not associate with his fellow officers, most of his friends are enlisted men, and he is an outspoken opponent of the war.
author: By Craig R. Whitney; Special to The New York Times

headline: How to Set a Date For Getting Out of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: THE graphic failure of the Laotian operation, begun with trumpets in February and prematurely terminated with heavy casualties and disorderly retreat before the end of March, produced a deeper (though at first a less clamorous) change of public sentiment than the extraordinary uproar occasioned by President Nixon's decision to send American forces into Cambodia a year ago. The Laos affair punctured the sturdy illusion that the South Vietnamese Army was moving steadily toward splendid self‐reliance; it brought home to millions of Americans that, whatever contrary hopes are sincerely held in the White House, the Nixon policy means in fact endless American military participation in an endless war; and that, so long as the war continues, there can be no return of American prisoners and no surcease from domestic turmoil and division.
author: By Townsend Hoopes

headline: Popularity of Nixon Is Found Steady
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 8—Public confidence in Richard M. Nixon's performance as President, which consistently declined during his first two years in office, has remained steady in the three months since the Laotian incursion, the Gallup Poll reported today.

headline: Roots of Involvement
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: John Franklin Campbell's piece on our hook, “Roots of Involvement. The U.S. in Asia, 1784–1971,” is plainly not a serious review. It is a put‐down, glib, cute, condescending. For this reason, we feel obliged to take issue with certain statements.
author: Marvin Kalb ELIE ABEL; New York City

headline: Rogers and Pope Paul Confer at the Vatican
lead_paragraph: ROME, May 8 (Reuters)—Secretary of Stale William P. Rogers spent. 45 minutes toddy with Pope Paul VI.

headline: 15,000 Rally in Capital to Urge Vietnam Victory
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 8—Several thousand people, including such varied groups as New York construction workers and Fundamentalist Bible classes of Appalachia, demonstrated peacefully here today in behalf of a military victory in Vietnam.
author: By John Berbers; Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam:
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Beyond the din of strident protest, the flailing of police nightsticks and the sting of tear gas here last week could be seen a new form of antiwar dissent.
author: —Richard Halloran

headline: Many Students Are Turning Away From Protest to Seek Own Goals
author: By Michael T. Kaufman

headline: NO AIRPORT
lead_paragraph: To THE EDITOR: The second of E. J. Kahn Jr.'s articles concerning his Far East trip, this one about Taipei, Saigon and other places (Travel section, April 18), was as entertaining as the first, though I suspect not always intentionally. His reference to the Saigon airport as “Cain Hut Thuoc” was surprising, since news dispatches when the airport has been under Vietcong fire have referred to it as Tansonnhut. Remembering a few words of Vietnamese, however, I realized that Mr. Kahn had miscopied the words from a sign which said “Cam Hut Thuoc,” which means No Smoking! In this respect he has joined another unwitting punster, Robert S. McNamara; the former Secretary of Defense originally pronounced the name of that sad country “Veet Nam,” to rhyme with “fleet Sam,” apparently thereby designating it in Vietnamese as “sick duck!”
author: Mark J. Eisner; Assistant Professor Cornell University Ithaca, N. Y

headline: Congress vs. President
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—As the youthful Mayday demonstrators were skirmishing in Washington last week in protest against the Vietnam war, the Nixon Administration had its own confrontation on Capitol Hill with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on legislation to end the war.
author: —John W. Finney

headline: An Epitaph Of Hopes On Future Budgets
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With apologies to Percy Bysshe Shelley and his “Ode to the West Wind”;
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr

headline: O'Brien Says Vietnam War Should Not Be Issue in ‘72
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9—Lawrence J. O'Brien, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that he hoped the Vietnam war would not be a campaign issue in 1972.

headline: 51 Cease‐Fire Violations Charged to Foe by Allies
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 — The 24‐hour allied truce in honor of Buddha's birthday ended at noon today with the South Vietnamese and Americans accusing the enemy of 51 cease‐fire violations, including the mining of a ferryboat that took the lives of 36 South Vietnamese civilians.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon's Strategy for 1972 Beginning to Take Shape
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9—Witho.ut completely doffing the Presidential hat ha pledged to wear after his disappointment at the 1970 elections, President Nixon has begun to channel larger amounts of his time and the resources of his staff to the political tests that await him in 1972.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: 5 Vietnamese Women Support Former G.I.'s Report of Slayings
lead_paragraph: NGHIAHANH, South Vietnam, May 9 (AP)—Five Vietnamese women say the Americans came in the morning and burned the houses, returned in the afternoon and killed 60 people in two groups, then bombed the village.

headline: STENNIS TO SEEK WAR POWER CURB
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9—Senator John C. Stennis, who has been a strong advocate of the Vietnam policies of Presidents Johnson and Nixon, said today that he would sponsor legislation that would prohibit a President from involving the United States in another extended war without Congressional approval.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 9—On May 8, 1970, shortly after American forces entered Cambodia, a dozen of Henry Kissinger's old colleagues at Harvard went down to Washington to talk with him. Mr. Kissinger or someone later put about that they had threatened to keep him from returning to Harvard, which was false. What they did do was express their despair at the Administration's war policy and their bewilderment at the part played in by a man of his intellect and experience.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: President Nixon either doesn't know or chooses to Ignore how, in 1954, Pierre Mendes‐France ended the French war against the people of Indochina. Otherwise, his tactics of gradual withdrawal from Indochina, Interspersed with sporadic counterattacks and invasions, would make even less sense than they do now.

headline: U.S. Writer Leaves Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 (Reuters)—Don Luce, the American who disclosed the use of the so‐called tiger cages — small stone cells at Con Son prison — left South Vietnam today after nearly 13 years as a journalist and social worker here. He went to Bangkok, Thailand, after having been refused permission to stay in this country any longer.

headline: Bunker Assays Vietnam Years
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 — Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker has just completed his fourth year in America's most crucial diplomatic post, conscious of past mistakes here, proud of the progress, confident of the future but aware of the dangers that lie ahead.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Buddhist Priest in Hue Burns Himself to Death
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 (AP) — A young Buddhist priest burned himself to death in Hue today in a protest against the war in Vietnam.

headline: FORCE IN VIETNAM IS CUT TO 267,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (AP) — The United States command announced to day the beginning of the with drawal of another division from South Vietnam, the deactiva tion of a major command and a cut of 6,300 more men.

headline: NIXON INQUIRY URGED IN ALLEGED KILLINGS
lead_paragraph: An antiwar group and a Viet nam veteran urged President Nixon yesterday to appoint commission to investigate the alleged murder by American soldiers of some 30 civilians in the South Vietnamese ham let of Truong Khanh in April, 1969.

headline: The Great Turnpike Bust
lead_paragraph: Four of us were on our way from Washington to New York on Sunday afternoon. It was the end of the April 24 weekend and we were stopped cold on the Jersey Turnpike in the same traffic jam that kept everyone, Icing hairs and straights alike, from getting home.
author: By Stephen Winter

headline: Hanoi Leader in Peking
lead_paragraph: PEKING, May 10 (Agence France‐Presse) — The North Vietnamese Communist party chief, Le Duan, arrived at Pe king today from Moscow after a long stay in the Soviet Union during which he attended the 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party. Mr. Duan was welcomed at the Peking airport by a high‐ranking Chinese delegation led by Pre mier Chou En Lai.

headline: Buckley Urges Local Help by Business
lead_paragraph: Senator James L. Buckley, warning yesterday of an “ero sion of public confidence in government,” attacked what he called indifference by business to community problems and “flattery of the mob” in con frontations like those in Wash ington last week.
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: Dead Monk Excommunicated
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (AP)—The Buddhist hierarchy today excommuni cated Thich Chon The, a 27‐ year‐old monk, who burned himself to death yesterday in Hue in protest against the war in Vietnam.

headline: BENATE TAKES UP DRAFT EXTENSION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 10 — The Senate began today a na tional security debate that os tensibly focused on extension of the draft but was broaden ing to include the Vietnam war and military commitments in Europe.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: DEFECTORSAYSHANOI HAS ALIEN ADVISERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (AP)—A high‐ranking defec tor from North Vietnam said today that Soviet, Chinese, Cuban, North Korean and French “military strategists” were advising Communist‐led forces fighting in South Vietnam.

headline: G.I. to Be Tried in Slaying Of Commander in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, May 10 (UPI)—A 20‐year‐old American private will be tried by general court‐martial on charge of premeditated murder in the shooting of his command ing officer, a United States Army spokesman said today.

headline: 2 U.S. SCIENTISTS WILL VISIT CHINA
lead_paragraph: Two American biologists are reported by their colleagues to be in China or about to go there from Hanoi, the North Vietnamese capital. A third American, a geophysicist from the University of California at Santa Cruz, is also said to have received permission to visit Peking shortly.
author: By Walter Sullivan

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Those who demand our immediate withdrawal from Vietnam have many strong arguments in their favor. Cer tainly our direct involvement in Indo china has proven to be politically un wise. The various governments of South Vietnam have not been as en lightened or as efficient as most Americans would like. Corruption, graft, and war profiteering are detesta ble anywhere.

headline: MITCHELL URGES ALL POLICE COPY CAPITAL'S TACTICS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 10— Attorney General John N. Mit chell urged the police in other cities today to copy the “de cisive” tactics, which included mass arrests, used by the Wash ington Police Department to break up the Mayday demon strations last week.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Laotian Soldiers Attack Four Hanoi Diplomats
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11 (AP)—Laotian Government soldiers and policemen as saulted four North Vietnam ese diplomats who walked out on a speech today by Premier Souvanna Phouma when he denounced the Ha noi Government for having sent troops into Laos.

headline: Murphy Defends Mass Arrests, But Cites Need to Protect Rights
lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that mass arrests were sometimes necessary but that “the police must be very careful about con stitutional rights.”

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul N. McCloskey has backed up his repeated threat to op pose President Nixon in the Presidential primaries unless the President changes his Southeast Asia policy.

headline: FUND PLAN VOTED BY EPISCOPALIANS
lead_paragraph: The Episcopal Diocese of New York approved a contro versial series of resolutions yes terday that will require virtually all of its churches to pay their own way within five years and to triple the money they must contribute to the diocese.
author: By Eleanor Blau

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We older citizens who traveled to Washington on April 24 to protest once more our Government's continua tion of the Vietnam war, made grievous error. We should have stayed in Washington and, added our support to those younger citizens who were trying by nonviolent methods to turn the policies of this nation around.

headline: Ex‐Private in Guard Gave Rennie Davis as Reference
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 11 — A private first class in the District of Columbia National Guard, who was discharged last month because of “admin istrative error,” listed Rennie Davis, the antiwar activist, as a character reference on his enlistment papers.

headline: Stennis Seeks War Curb on President
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 11 — John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Com mittee, introduced legislation today that would curb the power of Presidents to com mit the nation to war without the consent of Congress.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: A.F.L.‐ C.I.O. SCORES NIXON OVER FUNDS
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, May 11—The Ex ecutive Council of the A.F.L. C.I.O. said today that President Nixon's decision to withhold $12‐billion appropriated for do mestic programs by Congress betrayed “a firm determination to manipulate the Federal Treasury as a political tool in preparation for the 1972 elec tion campaign.”
author: By Agis Salpukas Special to The New York Times

headline: AGNEW DEPLORES ‘SCRUFFY’ YOUTHS
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 11 (UPI)—Vice President Agnew today described the thousands of antiwar demonstrators who recently crowded the nation's capital as “the same scruffy individuals that caused the dis ruptions in Chicago in 1968.”

headline: U.S. Reports a MIG‐21 Attack On Unarmed Plane Over Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 12 (AP)— A North Vietnamese MIG‐21 in terceptor attacked an unarmed United States reconnaissance plane twice over the Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos while a second MIG‐21 circled overhead Sunday, the American com mand disclosed today.

headline: Garment Union Deplores War But Endorses Policies of U.S.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 11 — Delegates to the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union here deplored today the “human and material cost of the bitter con flict in Vietnam.” At the same time, however, they warned that the world faced the dan ger of other Vietnams as long as totalitarian movements re mained “determined to impose their system of government and ideology on others, by force if necessary.”
author: By Damon Stetson Special to The New York Times

headline: Politics vs. Justice
lead_paragraph: However much he may know about marketing municipal bonds or managing a political campaign, Attorney Gen eral John Mitchell has again demonstrated that he under stands very little about the interdependence of law and liberty in a free society.

headline: Did Hanoi Open a Door?
lead_paragraph: In the face of President Nixon's frequently expressed desire for a negotiated settlement of the Indochina war, the Administration has taken a strangely negative ap proach to Hanoi's latest—if highly ambiguous—peace overtures. Doors toward negotiation were opened a crack on ApriI 29 by the North Vietnamese and Vietcong rep resentatives but instead of exploring where they led, Ambassador David Bruce last week either ignored them or seemed to slam them shut, presumably on instructions from Washington.

headline: Jersey Standard Chief Expects Gains in ’71
lead_paragraph: MIAMI, May 12—It was almost like a class reunion here today at the annual meeting of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
author: By William D. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: US, SAYS PLANES HIT GUNS IN NORTH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 (AP) — The United States command said today that Air Force Phantom jets had de stroyed 13 antiaircraft guns around the Mugia Pass in North Vietnam.

headline: Laos Reports MIG Attacks
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 12 (UPI)—A Government spokes man said today that North Vietnamese MIG‐21 jets flew bombing and strafing missions against Laotian Government troop positions in the Plaine des Jarres for the first time.

headline: Reflections on Calley
lead_paragraph: LA JOLLA, Calif.—The obscene haste with which a large part of the Amer ican people rushed to the support of a man convicted of multiple premedi tated murder of men, women and Chil dren, the obscene pride with which they even identified themselves with him is one of those rare historical events which reveal a hidden truth.
author: By Herbert Marcuse

headline: Capitol Peace Group Is Met by Mrs. Abzug
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) — Representative Bella S. Abzug, one of four legis lators severely criticized by their colleagues for welcom ing 1,500 antiwar protesters to the Capitol May 5, greeted participants in a 24 ‐ hour peace vigil on the Capitol steps today.

headline: Veterans for Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Despite statements to the contrary, 2.5 million Vietnam veterans have not dropped out or disappeared. With few exceptions, they are pursuing their in terrupted careers and education, free of self‐induced breast‐beating, proud of their contribution to. American defense and the Vietnamese future.
author: By Bruce N. Kesler

headline: U.S. Combat Deaths Pat at 34 for Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13 (Reuters) — Thirty four Americans and 360 South Vietnamese died in the Indochina war last week, military spokesmen said to day.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As antiwar activity boils up this spring, I think the importance given to flat statements on the morality of the war by all concerned, including the “five Democratic Presidential hope fuls” mentioned on your front page on April 22, is particularly interesting.

headline: Mitchell Charges Some Protest, Leaders Have Communist Relationships’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 13 — Attorney General John N. Mit chell said today that some of the leaders of last week's anti war protest had “Communist oriented or related back grounds.”
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON P.O.W. BID ACCEPTED IN HANOI
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Friday, May 14— Hanoi's official press agency said today that North Vietnam has agreed to accept formally a group of North Vietnamese prisoners of war held in South Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It has been said that an immediate withdrawal of U.S. forces from South Vietnam would result in an immediate Communist take‐over of South Viet nam and years of bloody retribution.

headline: MARINES IN ASHAU REPORT 2 ATTACKS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13 — North Vietnamese forces reportedly made two strong assaults yesterday against South Vietnamese ma rines near the enemy's long‐time operating base in the Ashau Valley.

headline: PARIS PEACE TALKS INTO FOURTH YEAR
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 13—The Viet nam peace conference began its fourth year today with each side blaming the other for the failure to stop the killing.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Bunker Encouraged by Move
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 14 (AP)— Ells worth Bunker, the United States Ambassador here, said today that North Vietnamese acceptance of Saigon's offer to free 570 prisoners was an “en couraging sign.” He said that he “hoped it would be the first step leading to the release of American and allied prisoners.” There was no immediate com ment from the South Vietnam ese Government.

headline: While Captive in Cambodia, War Reporter Kept Diary
lead_paragraph: Following is another article by Kate Webb, chief of United Press International's Pnompenh bureau, on her ex perience during 23 days as a prisoner of Vietnamese Com munist troops in Cambodia. Captured on April 8 with a Japanese newsman and four Cambodians during heavy fighting southwest of Pnom penh, she and her companions spent more than a week on the march and two weeks in a camp undergoing interroga tion and engaging in “con versations with the officers and casual chats with our guards.”

headline: Missile Sites Attacked
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Friday, May 14 (Reuters)—Two United States Thunderchief fighters fired mis siles at two North Vietnamese missile sites yesterday, in the 37th such attack this year, a United States military spokes man said today.

headline: U. S. Aides Voice Hope
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 13 State Department officials voiced cautious hope tonight that reports of a North Viet namese agreement to accept ailing prisoners held in South Vietnam would lead to the re lease of sick and wounded Americans held by Hanoi.

headline: Trial Date Set for Soldier Accused of Killing Officer
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 13 (UPI)—.The trial of a soldier charged with murder and attempted murder in the shooting of two United States Army majors after a dispute over a loud phonograph was set today for June 5.

headline: Abbie Hoffman Is Indicted On U.S. Antiriot Charges
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. May 13 (AP) —Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader, was indicted today on Federal antiriot charges stem ing from his alleged participa tion in the Mayday antiwar ac tivities in the nation's capital last week.

headline: SAIGON SAID TO HOLD 100,000 IN PRISONS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 13 (Reu ters)—Don Luce, who helped uncover the “tiger cage” prisons in South Vietnam, testi fied today that the Saigon Government held at least 100,000 political prisoners.

headline: Calley Denied Freedom Pending Review
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) —The Army refused today to let First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. go free while his conviction for murdering at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai is reviewed all the way up to President Nixon.

headline: ROGERS OPPOSES WAR‐POWER CURB
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 14—Secretary of State William P. Rogers told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that proposed legislation to restrict the President's war powers was impractical, probably unconstitutional and would weaken the President's ability to act in a crisis.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Force Reported Making New Sweep in East Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 15 (AP)—A new South Vietnamese sweep with United States air support is reported under way in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Long Island Marine Faces Trial As First to Aid Foe in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) —The Marine Corps ordered today a general court‐martial for a young sergeant accused of desertion and aiding the enemy while a prisoner of war in Vietnam.

headline: Mine Kills 5 G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, May 15 (Reuters)—Five American soldiers were killed when their personnel carrier hit a land mine 20 miles from Danang in Quangnam Province yesterday, the United States command reported today.

headline: Mary McCarthy again her own heroine—frozen foods a new villain
lead_paragraph: First it was Trotskyite periodicals, and psychoanalysis, and cocktail parties; next, progressive education and McCarthyism; then diaphragms, casseroles, Venetian blinds and enlightened pediatrics; now it is conservation, the Generation Gap and Vietnam: Mary McCarthy's tireless notation of the American Scene continues. Her new novel, “Birds of America,” provokes a peculiar double effect: here, we exclaim, is something we can point to in the year 2000 and find, embalmed in it, the very air of 1970; and yet this light and bright topicality of Miss McCarthy's, to judge by the fate of her earlier novels, has, like other radiant things, a very short half‐life, and, fictionally speaking, turns rapidly to lead, its occasion once past.
author: By Helen Vendler

headline: Brooklyn Boys Build Jet That Works
lead_paragraph: A group of students in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn have built their own airplane — a scaled‐down version of the McDonnell Douglas F‐4 Phantom II jet that is used for reconnaissance and combat in Vietnam.

headline: Britain Attracts More U.S. Academics
lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 15—For a variety of reasons, ranging from side effects of the Vietnam war to the economic crunch in the United States, American university teachers are coming to Britain in greater numbers than ever.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: Television
lead_paragraph: PFC. CARMINE MACEDONIO, 21, a postman's son from Williston Park, Long Island, died when his tank hit a mine in Vietnam. Wednesday evening at 8:30 on Channel 13, “Part. of the Family,” an NET documentary, visits Private Macedonio's parents and eight brothers and sisters, who talk about his life — and his death. The program also includes visits with the families of two students killed (luring anti‐war demonstrations at Kent State University and Jackson State University. Here are excerpts from the comments of Carmine Macedonio's parents and his younger brother Angelo.

headline: Saigon Reports New Push Into Parrot's Beak Region
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sunday, May 16—The South Vietnamese military command announced today that a multibattalion force had launched a new operation in the Parrot's Beak region of eastern Cambodia.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—It has been widely stated, in Congress and elsewhere, that the so‐called Mayday demonstrators in Washington, by their disruptive tactics, damaged the peace movement and alienated many of its supporters. But two weeks after the mass arrests in the streets of the nation's capital, seems more likely that the real damage was done by the forces of law and order to their own supposed cause.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: MOST IN POLL BACK WASHINGTON POLICE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) —A public opinion polling group says a heavy majority of people it interviewed disapproved of recent antiwar demonstrations in Washington and felt mass arrests of protesters were justified.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15—The ancient dilemmas of American politics are back in the headlines again: How to give the President the powers necessary to defend the nation in a time of nuclear weapons and international ballistic missiles, and still maintain the control of Congress. How to keep him strong enough to govern the nation without allowing him to impose his will on the people and their representatives in the Congress.
author: By James Reston

headline: Baptists Urge U.S. to Pull Out Of Indochina by End of the Year
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, May 15—The American Baptist Convention today called upon President Nixon and Congress to withdraw all United States military personnel from Indochina, except those in diplomatic service, ‘'hopefully” by Dec. 31, 1971. The vote was 1,451 in favor of the resolution and 199 against.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters War Crime Trials (Continued)
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Wilson Says U.S. Undercut 67 Move With Kosygin to Set Up Vietnam Talks
lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 15 — Harold Wilson, the former Labor party Prime Minister, says that he and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union came close to arranging Vietnam peace talks in February, 1967, but were sabotaged by the White House.
author: By Anthony Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Civilian Gets Top U.S. Post In Central Area of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15 (AP) — The United States command annonuced today that a civilian, John Paul Vann, was taking over as the senior American representative in South Vietnam's Central Highlands and central coastal provinces. It is the first time since the major troop buildup in 1965 that this post has been given to a civilian.

headline: Miss Kate Butler Righter. Bride In Buffalo of Donald J. Zammit
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, May 15 — Miss Kale Butler Righter, daughter of James H. Righter, publisher of The Buffalo Evening News, and Mrs. Righter, was married here today to Donald Joseph Zammit, who served as a sergeant with the First Air Cavalry in Vietnam. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Domenic Zammit of New York.

headline: G.I. Heroin Addiction Epidemic in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15—The use of heroin by American troops in Vietnam has reached epidemic proportions.
author: By Alvin M. Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: A time of pain and anger, gentleness and decency in Mississippi
lead_paragraph: Social problems are essentially boring. If they contain elements ‘of sex and violence, they have a chance of being popular for a while; but even with those things going for them, Great Issues soon become stale. Our flagging interest in yesterday's causes can only be revived, if at all, by some horrible new development, preferably involving bloodshed. The war in Vietnam had become a public bore until the invasion of Laos, which wakened us back into fiery protest for about 10 days. Martin Luther King, in his reasoned, steady campaign to uplift the conditions of his people (and therefore of all of us) had become a ho‐hum figure, a passe personage, until he was slain and thus elevated into the sure popularity of martyrdom.
author: By Dan Wakefield

headline: Nguyen Cao Ky: On the Sinking Boat
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam—South Vietnam is like a sinking boat, with deceptively good coat of paint outside, and a helmsman who is unfaithful, disloyal, and dishonest. A whirl of wind and the boat will sink to the bottom.
author: By Nguyen Cao Ky

headline: 4 Democratic Contenders Raise Curtainin Wisconsin

author: By Seth S. King Special to The New York Times

lead_paragraph: SAIGON, May 16 (Reuters)—North Vietnamese gunners fired two surface‐to‐air missiles at an American AC‐130 gunship as it flew over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos today, the United States command reported.

headline: SAIGON CUTS OFF CAMBODIAN NEWS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 16—South Vietnamese military authorities have moved to stop the flow of what they contend is inaccurate press information about operations in Cambodia.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I.'s Find It All in Saigon's Scag Alley
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam May 16 — Wartime overcrowding created the twisting, narrow lane and the mean, cramped cinder‐block houses that line it, but it is scag, or heroin, that gave it its G.I. name—Scag Alley—and that attracts the bored and unhappy American servicemen from nearby Tansonnhut Air Base.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Le Duan Leaves China
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, May 16 (Reuters) — The North Vietnamese Communist chief, Le Duan, has left China for Hanoi after a long tour which took him to the Soviet Union and China, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today.

headline: Pentagon Unsure of Total on Drug Use in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 16—The Department of Defense has been concerned for several years about the use of illicit’ drugs, especially heroin, by American servicemen stationed in Vietnam, a department spokesman said today.

headline: McGovern Asks $31‐Billion in Reform
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, May 16—Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, urged today that $31‐billion in current spending—most of it from the defense budget—be diverted in effort to eliminate poverty, pollution and racism by the end of this decade.

headline: A Few G. I. Addicts Aided in U. S.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N. C., May 13 —Jim is a 20‐year‐old private from Fairbanks, Alaska. Dennis is a 20‐year‐old giant of a soldier at 6 feet 4 inches, a private from the streets of Philadelphia.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: 1972 Candidates Off and Collecting

author: By Richard Reeves

headline: B‐52's Stage Raids
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, May 17 (AP)—Only light ground action was reported in South Vietnam today. United States B‐52 bombers again made raids in Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam.

author: By Warren S. Richardson

author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Pierre Elliott Trudeau yesterday became the first Canadian Prime Minister to make an official visit to the Soviet Union.

headline: ITALIAN DELEGATION EN ROUTE TO CHINA
lead_paragraph: ROME, May 17—A 74‐member economic delegation left for China today, led by a member of the Government and including representatives of major Italian industries.

headline: Foe Reported Advancing
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, May 17 (Agence France‐Presse) — North Vietnamese troops were today reported advancing in force toward Houei Kong, the Government's one remaining stronghold on the Boloven Plateau, 20 miles southeast of Paksong.

lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17 (AP)—The United States command announced today that American troop strength in South Vietnam was reduced by 4,600 men last week to 262,500, the lowest total in more than five years.

author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Seoul Police Seize 31 G.I.'s Protesting the Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, May 17 —South Korean riot police arTested 31 American soldiers who were demonstrating peacefully against the Vietnam war on a downtown street this evening.

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 17—“This court will come to order. This is the case of the people vs. D. Boone. The Attorney General will state the charge.”
author: By Russell Baker

headline: U.S. Ground Role Ending In Vietnam, Resor Says
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) —The Army Secretary, Stanley R. Resor, said today that by fall the United States would be “in a position to have no significant effect on ground combat activity” in Vietnam.

headline: Mylai lnquiry Hears Colonel Was Told About His Rights
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., May 17 (AP)—The Army's No. 2 civilian lawyer testified today that Col. Oran K. Henderson was informed of his rights on each of the five occasions lie appeared before a special Pentagon inquiry into an alleged cover‐up of the Mylai massacre.

headline: Agnew Says Hanoi Stalls On P.O.W.'s to Gain in Talks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 17 —Vice President Agnew said today that the United Slates and South Vietnam mere making final arrangements to repatriate 570 sick and wounded North Vietnamese who are prisoners of war.

headline: When Johnny Came Marching Home Again
lead_paragraph: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y.—The war in Vietnam ended last week for Mrs. Ethel Rausch and her family. It was over at 6:25 A.M. last Wednesday, when United States Marine Pfc. John Rausch, 19, came home.
author: By Joan Cook Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: ‘Part of the Family’ Examines Three Deaths
lead_paragraph: There is no easy approach to “Part of the Family.” ReVolving around the deaths of three young persons “caught in the crossfire of our nation's politicial and social crises,” it is really—somewhat like Edward Albee's fine “All Over"—about life, about the lives of the surviving family and friends. It is often deeply moving. It is occasionally, however, objectionably indulgent.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: U.S. Jets Attack in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, May 19 (Reuters)—Four United States supersonic jets attacked antiaircraft gun sites in North Vietnam in the last 48 hours, the United States military command reported today.

headline: TV Program for Common Cause Documents Opposition to War
lead_paragraph: Common Cause, the citizens lobby of which John W. Gardner, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, is chairman, is screening a special television program, “The People Speak Out on the War,” to respond to the views of President Nixon on the war in Indochina.

headline: Letters to the Editor

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Pusillanimous is the word to characterize the conduct of the Korean “police action” by President Harry S. Truman. Wretched characterizes the conduct of the Vietnam conflict by Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon.

headline: ARMY MYLAI INQUIRY SCORED BY DEFENSE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., May 18 (UPI)—A lawyer charged today that Lieut. Gen. William R. Peers consistently violated the constitutional rights of the soldiers he questioned about the 1968 Mylai slayings.

headline: Pleiku Center for Addicts Source of Dispute
lead_paragraph: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 12 — “They're always threatening to close the place down,” said Specialist 4 Robert Canberra, a 20‐year‐old Army medical corpsman who once used heroin and who now runs Highland House where addicts in the 52d Combat Aviation Battalion at Camp Holloway can come to try to get off drugs.

headline: Protests in Capital Cost $5.5‐Million

headline: ENEMY OVERRUNS A 2D TOWN IN LAOS

author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Base Sought
lead_paragraph: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 19 (AP)—Seven hundred South Vietnamese troops were re ported combing an area along the Laotian border today, searching for a major North Vietnamese base and command headquarters.

headline: GENERAL DEMOTED OVER MYLAI CASE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 19 — The Army disciplined two gen erals today for failing to con duct an adequate investigation into the slayings of South Viet namese civilians at Mylai in 1968.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Collegians to Tour Pacific
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, May 19 (AP) —Eight college football players will visit American servicemen in Pacific‐area hospitals and Vietnam this summer, the Na tional Collegiate Athletic Asso ciation announced today. Among the players are Johnny Musso, Alabama halfback; Ly dell Mitchell, Penn State half back; Stan Maudlin, Texas line backer, and Rocky Long, New Mexico quarterback.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, May 19— An editorial that will be published in principal Peking publications tomorrow portrays the United States Government as an ad ministration beset by troubles at home and abroad.

headline: Souvanna Welcomes U.S.‐China Thaw
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 19 —Premier Souvanna Phouma today praised China's historic ally nonaggressive attitude to ward Laos and expressed the hope that an improvement in Chinese‐American relations would lead to restraints on What he termed North Viet nam's expansionism.

lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 19 — The United States, while turning the South Viet namese Air Force into one of the largest in the world, is at the same time sharply limiting its tactical and strategic capa bilities on the assumption that the war will continue to wind down.

lead_paragraph: Morton Sobell, who was con victed as a Soviet spy in 1951, won a Federal Court decision here yesterday permitting him to participate in demonstra tions of political dissent.
author: By Arnold H. Lubasch

headline: TURNPIKE PROTEST COMES UP IN COURT
lead_paragraph: BELLMAWR, N. J., May 20 (AP)—Cases of 97 peace dem onstrators accused of blocking traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike for five hours April 25 were dealt with in a nine hour court session here today.

headline: Censured General Says He Is an Army Sacrifice

headline: Vietnamese at Saigon Airport, in a Sharp Change, Intercept, Smugglers
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21—The airport here, long a smuggler's dream, is turning into a nightmare not only for smugglers but also for ordinary travelers, much to the delight of the American advisers who have been urging strict meas ures for months.

headline: LAIRD URGES SAIGON TO ACT ON NARCOTICS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 21 (Reu ters)—Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird today said the South Vietnamese Government must be more realistic in facing up to the problem of how to stop narcotics from reaching American servicemen.

headline: Patents of the Week
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 21— A lightweight armored seat, for which a patent will be granted June 1, is already in general use by helicopter pilots in Vietnam. headline: Carrier Returns to War

headline: The World

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22 — More than two‐thirds of the people questioned in a recent survey said that they believed the Nixon Administration was failing to tell the American people all they should know about the conduct of the Viet nam war, the Gallup poll said today.

headline: Dean Acheson: On Winding Down
lead_paragraph: The present debate about the Presi dent's intentions regarding troop with drawals from Vietnam arises from what he has said rather than from what he has done. The logic of the facts is plain. When Mr. Nixon an nounced the beginning of troop with drawals, the authorized troop strength in Vietnam was 549,000; actual troop strength probably a few thousand less. Withdrawals actually made since that time, plus the 100,000 announced by the President to be made by December 31, 1971, will amount to 365,000, leav ing a remainder from authorized. strength of about 185,000 in Vietnam. The average withdrawal rate over the thirty months of the operation has been 12,000 per month.
author: By Dean Acheson

headline: Diplomatic Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24— The warming breezes from abroad are treating the Nixon Administration to its first big diplomatic thaw and causing the men around the President to toy with the immodest thought that they must he do ing something right—in rela tions with Moscow and Pe king, in promot ing cease‐fire in the Middle East and perhaps even in managing the withdrawal from Southeast Asia. The pol iticians around the White House are especially pleased with the news about arms control and troop negotia tions and Ping‐Pong, which lets their President shine in his favorite role of statesman and should leave the Demo crats doubting that they can ever steal the peace issue from an incumbent.

headline: IN THE NATION

headline: A Volunteer Army?

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the best‐known opponent of ending the draft, articulated this con cern in a recent speech: “It is unwise to insulate from the horrors of war middle and upper class Americans who might lead the pretest against sense less foreign adventures. I frankly would question, for example, whether the current pressure for de‐escalation of the Indochina war would be as great if young men from every social background were not threatened with service in that war.”

headline: Screen: 'The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus'
lead_paragraph: If you recall last year's Off Broadway "Chicago 70," which was put on by the Toronto Workshop Company at the Martinique Theater here, you're hereby apprised that the 16mm. color film version on view at the Film Forum through next weekend is essentially the same improvisational dramatization. It includes excerpts of the 1969-70 trial of the "Chicago 8" with infusions of "Alice in Wonderland," juvenile classroom recitations and pseudo-radio broadcasts. The film version, labeled "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus," is decidedly true to its title as "circus," "conspiracy" and justifiable polemics, but it is rarely moving as movie drama.Basically, a moviegoer is affected by what he sees and even if the truth, like the politics of our time, is both tragic and comic, it has to be strongly visualized as well as declared on screen. There is a great speaking of minds from the actual record in "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus" but, unfortunately, there is not a great deal to stir the hearts or the eyes of the uninitiate.As noted, the polemics as well as the confusion of a baffled Judge Julius J. Hoffman facing the taunts and life-style (and the psychedelic dress) of the disparate likes of Abbie Hoffman, Bobby Seale, Allen Ginsberg (reciting some of his explicitly sexual poems) and Country Joe McDonald singing his anti-Vietnam rock, are forceful and to the point.One is also Impressed that maintaining law and order before defendants and attorneys who are trying to stress that the court is not their idea of law and order any more than is Mayor Richard J. Daly's rule of Chicago strikes effective notes for both the Establishment and a younger generation divorced from it.Kerry Feltham, the director, who has employed practically the same cast that George Luscombe used in the play, has drawn forthright declamations from all of them, both black and white. And, it must be noted that, while it is sometimes confusing, different actors are sometimes switched to play the same role, such as Judge Hoffman's, and do prove their versatility.The cast, to name a few such as Mel Dixon, Jim Lawrence, Peter Faulkner, Neil Walsh and Diane Grant and not to slight the others, are Yippie, hippie and serious enough to project authentic dedication to their art and dialogue. But like the documentary "Breathing Together: Revolution of the Electric Family," seen here last month and also dealing with the trial, "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus," which was photographed on sets with a mirror background, is generally as static as a photographed play.What the Toronto Workshop Company has to say is obviously ingenious theater even if it is political and perhaps partisan. But it is, sadly enough, good rhetoric that does not add up to an exciting or innovative film.
author: By A. H. Weiler
